title: Russo-Georgian War (2008)
summary: Five-day war between Russia and Georgia over the breakaway regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia. Russia invaded Georgia, defeated Georgian forces, and recognized South Ossetia and Abkhazia as independent states. Seen as precursor to Crimea and Ukraine.

russian_perspective.official_narrative: Georgia attacked South Ossetia, committing genocide against Ossetians and killing Russian peacekeepers. Russia conducted a humanitarian intervention to protect civilians and restore peace. Georgia was armed and encouraged by the West (NATO) to attack.

core_claims: Georgia initiated the war by attacking Tskhinvali (South Ossetia capital)
Georgian forces committed genocide and ethnic cleansing
Russia was protecting Russian peacekeepers legally stationed there
South Ossetia and Abkhazia have right to self-determination

key_quotes.speaker: Dmitry Medvedev
key_quotes.quote: We don't have any other choice but to recognize the independence of South Ossetia and Abkhazia.

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: War has started. The Georgian troops have been already eliminated from South Ossetia's territory.

western_perspective.official_narrative: Russia provoked Georgia into military action, then used it as pretext for disproportionate invasion. Russia's recognition of breakaway regions violated Georgia's territorial integrity and international law.
counter_arguments: Russia advanced into undisputed Georgian territory (Gori)
Recognition of breakaway regions violated international norms

verified_claims: Georgia launched artillery attack on Tskhinvali on Aug 7
Russia invaded Georgia proper (beyond South Ossetia) on Aug 9-10
Ceasefire brokered by France (Sarkozy) on August 12
Russia recognized South Ossetia and Abkhazia independence on Aug 26
Only Nicaragua, Venezuela, Nauru, Syria recognize the territories
EU investigation: Both sides violated international law
disputed_claims: Who started the war (provocations preceded Georgian attack)

propaganda_techniques_observed: Fait accompli (rapid military victory, then recognition)
